Question_1.Context: The study focused on identifying functional OMTs involved in the formation of methoxyflavonoids in orange plants. CsOMT16 was one of the CsOMTs examined for its OMT activity with flavonoid substrates.
Question_1.Question: Which CsOMT catalyzed the regiospecific 3’‑O‑methylation of flavonoids?
Question_1.Source: Of the examined CsOMTs, CsOMT16 catalyzed the regiospecific 3’‑O‑methylation of flavonoids to the respective 3’‑methoxyflavonoids.

Question_2.Context: The study investigated the substrate preferences of CsOMT16 by examining its OMT activity with various flavonoid substrates.
Question_2.Question: Which flavonoid substrate showed the strongest OMT activity with CsOMT16?
Question_2.Source: CsOMT16 showed the strongest OMT activity toward quercetin among the examined flavonoids.

Question_3.Context: The study discussed the kinetic parameters of CsOMT16 with different flavonoid substrates to understand its catalytic efficiency.
Question_3.Question: Which flavonoid substrate had the lowest Km value for CsOMT16?
Question_3.Source: CsOMT16 had the lowest Km value of 0.25 µM for rhamnetin.

Question_4.Context: The study evaluated the biotransformation of flavonoids using CsOMT16-transformed E. coli cells to produce 3’-methoxyflavonoids.
Question_4.Question: Which flavonoid substrate was almost consumed within 2 hours by the E. coli cells transformed with CsOMT16?
Question_4.Source: Eriodictyol was almost consumed by the E. coli cells within 2 hours and was converted to an equivalent amount of homoeriodictyol.

Question_5.Context: The study highlighted the successful production of 3’-methoxyflavonoids by biotransformation using CsOMT16-transformed E. coli cells.
Question_5.Question: Which 3’-methoxyflavonoid exhibited anti-microbial activities against bacteria and fungi?
Question_5.Source: Chrysoeriol and isorhamnetin exhibit anti-microbial activities against bacteria and fungi.

Question_6.Context: The study discussed the substrate preferences of CsOMT16 and its ability to catalyze the 3’-O-methylation of flavonoids.
Question_6.Question: Which flavonoid substrate did CsOMT16 show the lowest Vmax value for?
Question_6.Source: The Vmax value for rhamnetin was the lowest among those for the examined substrates.

Question_7.Context: The study investigated the regiospecific methylation of flavonoids by CsOMT16 and its application in the biotechnological production of methoxyflavonoids.
Question_7.Question: Which flavonoid substrate did CsOMT16 convert to isorhamnetin?
Question_7.Source: Quercetin was converted to isorhamnetin by CsOMT16.

Question_8.Context: The study discussed the production of 3’-methoxyflavonoids using CsOMT16-transformed E. coli cells and their potential applications.
Question_8.Question: Which 3’-methoxyflavonoid has been reported to have anti-cancer, anti-inflammatory, and anti-oxidation activities?
Question_8.Source: Isorhamnetin has been reported to have anti-cancer, anti-inflammatory, and anti-oxidation activities.

Question_9.Context: The study focused on the biochemical properties of CsOMT16 and its role in the formation of methoxyflavonoids.
Question_9.Question: Which CsOMT was identified as a putative candidate for flavonoid OMT in orange based on phylogenetic relationships and conservation of signature motifs?
Question_9.Source: The phylogenetic relationships with other functional OMTs and the conservation of the signature motifs suggest that CsOMT16 is a putative candidate of FOMTs in orange.

Question_10.Context: The study investigated the heterologous expression and purification of CsOMTs to examine their biochemical properties.
Question_10.Question: Which CsOMT was successfully expressed in E. coli BL21 cells at 25 °C of growth temperature by 0.1 mM IPTG?
Question_10.Source: CsOMT16 was successfully expressed in E. coli BL21 cells at 25 °C of growth temperature by 0.1 mM IPTG.
